titleproper.value:
Guide to the Brooklyn Navy Yard land acquisition records
                    <num>1985.044</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Matthew Gorham

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2011-11-18T16:16-0500</date>

unittitle.value: Brooklyn Navy Yard land acquisition records

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Brooklyn Navy Yard land acquisition records, 1985.044, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
Source and date of acquisition unknown. The records were formally accessioned in 1985.

The origins of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, officially known as the New York Naval Shipyard, date back to 1801, when the United States Navy acquired what had previously been a small, privately owned shipyard in order to construct naval vessels. Historic vessels constructed or launched at the Navy Yard include Robert Fulton's steam frigate, the 
                <emph render="italic">Fulton</emph>, the USS 
                <emph render="italic">Arizona</emph>, the USS 
                <emph render="italic">Missouri</emph>, and the USS 
                <emph render="italic">Antietam</emph>. During the Civil War, the Navy Yard employed about 6,000 people. By 1938, it provided jobs for over 10,000 people. When the Defense Department ceased shipbuilding activities at the Navy Yard in 1966, 88 vessels had been manufactured at the facility. It had also grown to encompass 291 acres with 270 major buildings, 24 miles of railroad tracks, 23,278 linear feet of crane tracks, 18 miles of paved roads, 16,495 feet of berthing space, 9 piers, 6 dry docks, and 22 shops housing 98 different trades. In 1967, the Brooklyn Navy Yard was acquired by the City of New York and was converted for private commercial use.

Records from the District Court of the United States for the Eastern District of New York detailing the acquisition of land for the expansion of the New York Naval Shipyard (commonly known as the Brooklyn Navy Yard), dated 1940.

subject.value: Real property |z New York (State) |z Kings County

corpname.value: United States. District Court (New York : Eastern District).
